sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 

2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(l)

Given the standard enthalpies of formation are: 
ΔHf°(H2O(l)) = -285.8 kJ/mol 
ΔHf°(H2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol 
ΔHf°(O2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol 

Assume all reactants and products are at standard state conditions.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given reaction:

2H2(g) + O2(g) → 2H2O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation are:

ΔHf°(H2O(l)) = -285.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(O2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = [2 × ΔHf°(H2O(l))] - [2 × ΔHf°(H2(g)) + ΔHf°(O2(g))]

ΔH°(reaction) = [2 × (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (0 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)]

ΔH°(reaction) = (-571.6 kJ/mol) - (0 kJ/mol)

ΔH°(reaction) = -571.6 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -571.6 kJ/mol.
